poynter.org.notes: The Poynter Institute for Media Studies is a non-profit school for journalism located in St. Petersburg, Florida. The school is the owner of The Tampa Bay Times newspaper. The school began on May 29, 1975.  This a low bias source with outstanding writing and journalism.  They also perform comprehensive Fact Checks.

pogo.org.name: Project on Government Oversight
pogo.org.notes: The Project On Government Oversight (POGO), founded in 1981, is an independent non-profit organization in the United States which investigates and seeks to expose corruption and other misconduct. POGO assists whistleblowers and investigates federal agencies, Congress, and government contractors.  This is a solid evidence based source.

publicpolicypolling.com.name: Public Policy Polling (PPP)
publicpolicypolling.com.notes: Public Policy Polling (PPP) is a U.S. Democratic polling firm based in Raleigh, North Carolina.  Political research firm YouGov found PPP’s gubernatorial polls to have the lowest average margin of error among national firms that polled in at least ﬁve gubernatorial races in the month preceding the election. In 2013 columnist Nate Cohn described PPP as a liberal pollster, although according to statistician Nate Silver, PPP had a tendency to slightly lean Republican as of September 2016.

prri.org.name: Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI)
prri.org.notes: The Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI) is an American nonprofit, nonpartisan research and education organization that conducts public opinion polls on a variety of different topics. PRRI is a public resource for journalists, scholars, policy makers and the general public. PRRI is a member of the National Council of Public Polls and is a founding member of the Transparency Initiative at the American Association of Public Opinion Research.

parallax.news.name: Parallax News (PXW)
parallax.news.notes: This source asks a topical question and then presents 3 different perspectives from political figures or experts.  The people may be biased, but the presentation by the site is non-biased and informative.

news.cn/english.name: Reference News (Xinhua)
news.cn/english.notes: Daily newspaper from China that presents mostly unbiased reporting of international and USA news.

reporterslab.org.name: Reporters Lab
reporterslab.org.notes: The Reporters’ Lab explores new forms of journalism, including fact-checking, empowering democracies and holding governments accountable, and structured journalism, which creates new forms of storytelling and beat reporting. The Reporters’ Lab has minimal bias and is highly factual.

represent.us.name: Represent.Us
represent.us.notes: A website dedicated to ending corruption in politics.  Does have a slight left leaning bias, but generally factual in news and data.

reuters.com.name: Reuters
reuters.com.notes: A highly reputable news reporting service. Reuters has a policy of taking a “value-neutral approach.”  Reuters’ editorial policy states: “We are committed to reporting the facts and in all situations avoid the use of emotive terms. The only exception is when we are quoting someone directly or in indirect speech.” Reuters does not offer opinion and just reports news.

riverbender.com.name: RiverBender.com
riverbender.com.notes: Riverbender is a portal serving local and national news, classifieds, event calendars and Alton guides to restaurants, shopping and attractions with coupons. Riverbender provides local news with minimal bias and also uses the Associated Press to deliver news to the website.

rollcall.com.name: Roll Call
rollcall.com.notes: Roll Call is a solid “just the facts” news source, featuring a writing staff with an impressive set of credentials in political journalism. The articles are well sourced, and the information is presented “as is” with very minimal bias. While looking through the articles one in particular caught my attention. The article addressed the much hyped, on both sides, possibility of using National Guard troops to assist ICE in finding and deporting illegal immigrants. There is no real substance to the claim at this point, which came from an early draft of a “what if” style memo that never reached any official level.  I’ve read numerous articles on the issue, and Roll Call’s article was the fairest and least biased I have seen.

sciencedebate.org.name: Science Debate
sciencedebate.org.notes: Science Debate is a website dedicated to getting politicians to discuss scientific issues.

scoopnest.com.name: Scoopnest
scoopnest.com.notes: Scoopnest is an online service that collects news “tweets” from a wide range of sources.  They also provide the ability to filter by topics such as politics or health, etc.  The Twitter sources it pulls from range from left to right and in the middle.  While this source does pull information from biased sources, Scoopnest itself is not providing commentary and remains neutral.  Hence we give Scoopnest a least biased rating for providing news from all sources.

scotusblog.com.name: SCOTUSblog
scotusblog.com.notes: SCOTUSblog is a law blog written by lawyers, law professors, and law students about the Supreme Court of the United States. The site tracks cases before the Court from the certiorari stage through the merits stage. The site live blogs as the Court announces opinions and grants cases, and sometimes has information on the Court’s actions published before either the Court or any other news source does. In reviewing this source I could not find any use of loaded language and all content was factually based. Most information is simply reporting of what is happening. This is a low biased source for SCOTUS information. (D. Van Zandt)

snopes.com.name: Snopes
snopes.com.notes: Fact checking and myth debunking site.  Well sourced and accurate.

stripes.com.name: Stars and Stripes
stripes.com.notes: Stars and Stripes is an American military newspaper that focuses and reports on matters concerning the members of the United States Armed Forces. It operates from inside the Department of Defense, but is editorially separate from it, and its First Amendment protection is safeguarded by the United States Congress, to whom an independent ombudsman, who serves the readers’ interests, regularly reports. Stars and Stripes is balanced in reporting and is low in editorial bias. They source to credible information.

statnews.com.name: Stat (News)
statnews.com.notes: According the Stat about page: “STAT delivers fast, deep, and tough-minded journalism. We take you inside science labs and hospitals, biotech boardrooms, and political backrooms. We dissect crucial discoveries. We examine controversies and puncture hype. We hold individuals and institutions accountable. We introduce you to the power brokers and personalities who are driving a revolution in human health.” STAT is produced by Boston Globe Media. In my review of this site I feel that STAT delivers on their mission. Articles are well researched and direct, without use of loaded words. There is a very slight leftward bias in story selection, but not enough to move to the Left-Center category.

stimson.org.name: Stimson Center
stimson.org.notes: Founded in 1989, the Stimson Center is a nonprofit, nonpartisan think tank devoted to addressing transnational challenges in order to enhance global peace and economic prosperity.  Given 5-Star (Highly Transparent) rating by Transparify’s 2015 report.

stocknewsusa.com.name: Stock News USA
stocknewsusa.com.notes: Stock News USA is a news website that presents news with minimal bias. Headlines are not sensational and all stories have links to credible sources. Essentially, Stock News USA takes top news stories of the day and repackages them as direct, easy to read stories.

stratfor.com.name: Stratfor
stratfor.com.notes: Stratfor is an American publisher and global intelligence company founded in 1996 in Austin, Texas, by George Friedman, who was the company’s chairman.  Stratfor is a well respected source for military intelligence.

sunlightfoundation.com.name: Sunlight Foundation
sunlightfoundation.com.notes: The Sunlight Foundation is an American 501(c)(3) nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that advocates for open government. The organization was founded in April 2006 with the goal of increasing transparency and accountability in the United States Congress, the executive branch, and in state and local governments. The foundation’s primary focus is the role of money in politics. The organization seeks to increase campaign finance regulations and disclosure requirements.  The Sunlight Foundation’s donors include the Open Society Foundations, The Pew Charitable Trusts, the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Ford Foundation, the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, the Omidyar Network, Bloomberg Philanthropies, and the Laura and John Arnold Foundation. Sunlight is a great resource for tracking money in politics and has minimal bias.

taskandpurpose.com.name: Task and Purpose
taskandpurpose.com.notes: Task and Purpose (TAP) is a military centric web site that covers a wide range of military related subjects. The content ranges from current affairs to gear and gadgets, with a focus on veterans, the men and women currently serving, and their families. While the Opinion page does reveal a slight Left Bias overall, it is confined to the Opinion page, as is appropriate. Despite the sometimes controversial nature of the content covered, the articles on TAP are consistently apolitical, presenting the facts with a minimum of editorializing. The factual, well sourced, and fairly presented content, combined with the overall quality of the site, earns TAP a Least Biased rating. (D. Kelley)

texastribune.org.name: Texas Tribune
texastribune.org.notes: The Texas Tribune is a nonprofit media organization based in Austin, Texas. Its website and content in various delivery platforms serves as an alternative news source for Texas, with a goal of supplementing mainstream media sources. Low biased reporting.

thatsnonsense.com.name: That’s Nonsense
thatsnonsense.com.notes: That’s Nonsense is a resource for internet and social media scams and hoaxes.

thebureauinvestigates.com.name: The Bureau of Investigative Journalism
thebureauinvestigates.com.notes: The Bureau of Investigative Journalism (typically abbreviated to TBIJ or “the Bureau”) is a nonprofit news organisation based in London. It was founded in 2010 to pursue “public interest” investigations, funded through philanthropy. The Bureau works with publishers and broadcasters to maximize the impact of its investigations. TBIJ is always very well sourced, factual and written professionally. This is a strong source for deep investigations that are evidence based.

chronicle.com.name: The Chronicle of Higher Education
chronicle.com.notes: The Chronicle of Higher Education is a newspaper and website that presents news, information, and jobs for college and university faculty and Student Affairs professionals (staff members and administrators). A subscription is required to read some articles.

theconversation.com/us.name: The Conversation
theconversation.com/us.notes: The Conversation is an independent, not-for-profit media outlet that uses content sourced from the academic and research community. Present news with a centrist view point and relatively non-biased journalism.

thediplomat.com.name: The Diplomat Magazine
thediplomat.com.notes: The Diplomat is an online international news magazine covering politics, society, and culture in the Asia-Pacific region. It is based in Tokyo, Japan. Reporting with neutral wording and low bias.

economist.com.name: The Economist
economist.com.notes: The Economist is an English-language weekly news magazine owned by the Economist Group and edited in offices in London. Centrist views and straightforward non-biased reporting.  They carefully label opinion pieces.

fakenewscodex.com.name: The Fake News Codex
fakenewscodex.com.notes: The Fake News Codex is a website created to identify “news” sites that are fake, extremely misleading, or satirical. They do not list highly biased sites, but rather focus solely on Fake News sources.  Many of the sites listed on The Fake News Codex are also listed on our website in the Conspiracy, Satire or Questionable Source categories. All in all the site is laid out nicely and is a good resource.

thehumanist.com.name: The Humanist Magazine
thehumanist.com.notes: The Human Magazine is published by the American Humanist Association.  It is a Bi-monthly publication that covers everything from science and religion to media and technology to politics and popular culture.  Extremely well sourced and factual.  Leans slightly to the left politically.

indianexpress.com.name: The Indian Express
indianexpress.com.notes: The Indian Express is an English-language Indian daily newspaper. It is published in Mumbai by Indian Express Group.  Low biased coverage of the USA.

thejakartapost.com.name: The Jakarta Post
thejakartapost.com.notes: The Jakarta Post is a daily English language newspaper in Indonesia. The paper is owned by PT Bina Media Tenggara, and the head office is in the nation’s capital, Jakarta. The Jakarta Post has some state bias, but reports very factually on international news. They have won journalism awards for their coverage if international politics.

jpost.com.name: The Jerusalem Post
jpost.com.notes: The Jerusalem Post is a broadsheet newspaper based in Jerusalem, publishing only English and French editions.  Formerly regarded as left-wing, the paper underwent a noticeable shift to the right in the late 1980s.  From 2004, under then editor-in-chief David Horovitz, the paper took a more centrist position.  Is biased towards Israel, but very centrist in world affairs.

thejournal.ie.name: TheJournal.ie
thejournal.ie.notes: TheJournal.ie is an internet news publication in Ireland. It is a mixture of original and aggregated content.  Founded in 2010 and is a low bias source.

themarshallproject.org.name: The Marshall Project
themarshallproject.org.notes: The Marshall Project is a nonprofit nonpartisan online journalism organization focusing on issues related to criminal justice in the United States, led by former hedge fund manager Neil Barsky and former New York Times executive editor Bill Keller. Present information with minimal bias and proper sourcing.

soas.ac.uk/lmei/meil.name: The Middle East in London
soas.ac.uk/lmei/meil.notes: The Middle East in London was started in 1974. The magazine is part of the London Middle East Institute and is published by the Institute on a bi-monthly basis.  Each issue is organized around a central theme related to the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), and the variety of themes is constantly growing. Very low biased, neutral well sourced information.

themoderatevoice.com.name: The Moderate Voice
themoderatevoice.com.notes: Centrist views, but does have opinion pieces that range from moderate left to right.

thenews.mx.name: The News (Mexico City)
thenews.mx.notes: Generally pulls news from the AP and Reuters.  Daily newspaper from Mexico City, Mexico.

observatory.journalism.wisc.edu.name: The Observatory
observatory.journalism.wisc.edu.notes: The Observatory is produced by the University of Wisconsin-Madison School of Journalism and Mass Communication. The website performs fact checks and also publishes fact checks from other reliable providers. Low biased and well sourced fact checks.

outlook.monmouth.edu.name: The Outlook (Monmouth University)
outlook.monmouth.edu.notes: The Outlook is Monmouth University’s student run newspaper since 1933.  The reporting is relatively free of bias.

phnompenhpost.com.name: The Phnom Penh Post
phnompenhpost.com.notes: The Phnom Penh Post is a daily English-language newspaper published in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Founded in 1992 by publisher Michael Hayes and Kathleen O’Keefe, it is Cambodia’s oldest English-language newspaper. It is printed in full-color tabloid format. (Wikipedia)

theskimm.com.name: The Skimm
theskimm.com.notes: The Skimm is an email newsletter publisher launched in 2012.  The Skimm focuses on a short, simple, and easy-to-read version of the news, and is specifically targeted at urban women aged 22-34.  The stories are short and have little bias added.

timesofindia.indiatimes.com.name: Times of India
timesofindia.indiatimes.com.notes: Outstanding non-biased reporting on American and international news.

thewhim.com.name: The Whim
thewhim.com.notes: The Whim claims on their website: “We’d rather be second and accurate than be first and wrong. The Whim News Desk is a dedicated team of researchers and investigators committed to presenting the news without bias.” Our assessment reveals that The Whim is low biased and does not use loaded language. They stick to presenting facts about news stories and present both sides of issues.

thirdway.org.name: Third Way
thirdway.org.notes: Third Way is a Washington, D.C.-based public policy think tank founded in 2005. The think tank develops policy ideas, conducts public opinion research and hosts issue briefings. The organization has four policy divisions: Economics, National Security, Clean Energy, and Social Policy & Politics. Third Way develops and advocates for policies that it says represent the “vital center.”

transparency.org.name: Transparency International
transparency.org.notes: Transparency International (TI) is an international non-governmental organization which is based in Berlin, Germany, and was founded in 1993. Its nonprofit purpose is to take action to combat corruption and prevent criminal activities arising from corruption. It publishes for example the Global Corruption Barometer and the Corruption Perceptions Index. Offers low biased well source information on corruption.

transpartisanreview.com.name: Transpartisan Review
transpartisanreview.com.notes: Transpartisan Review (TR), founded by A. Lawrence Chickering and James S. Turner is an online magazine for the transpartisan political belief. Akin to Third Way politics and centrism in some respects, transparitsan politics eschews a left or right view and promotes cooperation from all sides; left, right, center, etc, with the goal of finding solutions instead. The articles in TR are factual and well sourced, and the only bias evident is towards the transpartisan belief. (D. Kelley)

truthbetold.news.name: Truth Be Told
truthbetold.news.notes: TruthBeTold.news (formerly called HU Insight)  is a non-profit, non-partisan website and digital network, run and edited from Howard University’s Department of Media, Journalism and Film in the School of Communications. It uses journalistic skills and crowdsourced information to play a leading role by examining claims about the black community in public debate. Truth Be Told is a low biased source that does fact checks on issues related to the black community. All articles are well sourced with the use of minimal loaded words.

turkeyandfacts.com.name: Turkey and Facts (Dogruluk Payi)
turkeyandfacts.com.notes: Turkey and Facts is the first fact checking website in Turkey.  The content comes from the Turkish language version at dogrulukpayi.com.  This is a well sourced fact check site.

tvw.org.name: TVW Washington State
tvw.org.notes: TVW is Washington’s public affairs network, providing gavel-to-gavel coverage of Washington State Legislature sessions and coverage of the Washington State Supreme Court and public affairs events. It is widely considered the model state level equivalent of C-SPAN.

upi.com.name: United Press International (UPI)
upi.com.notes: United Press International (UPI) is an international news agency whose newswires, photo, news film, and audio services provided news material to thousands of newspapers, magazines and radio and television stations during the 20th century.  UPI is similar to Reuters and the AP, but on a smaller scale today.  Provides low biased news content.

usafacts.org.name: USA Facts
usafacts.org.notes: USAFacts is a data-driven portrait of the American population, our government’s finances, and government’s impact on society. They are a non-partisan, not-for-profit civic initiative and have no political agenda or commercial motive. USAFacts relies exclusively on publicly available government data sources. They don’t make judgments or prescribe specific policies. Essentially this is a search engine for statistical data, such as “What is the Crime rate?” etc. This is a valuable resource for fact driven content.

usaspending.gov.name: USA Spending
usaspending.gov.notes: USAspending.gov is the publicly accessible, searchable website mandated by the Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act of 2006 to give the American public access to information on how their tax dollars are spent.

usatoday.com.name: USA Today
usatoday.com.notes: USA Today is a national American daily middle-market newspaper published and owned by the Gannett Company.  It has the 3rd largest distribution rate in the United States.  They report news with minimal bias and a simple to read format for general audiences. May have a very slight left leaning editorial bias.

vocativ.com.name: Vocativ
vocativ.com.notes: Vocativ is a media and technology company founded by Mati Kochavi. Vocativ uses proprietary data-mining technology to explore the deep web in order to discover stories and generate original content. In reviewing this website’s content I found minimal loaded language and properly sourced information. There does appear to be a slight leftward bias in story selection, but not enough to rate this source anything other than least biased. (D. Van Zandt)

voanews.com.name: Voice of America
voanews.com.notes: Voice of America (VOA) is a United States government-funded multimedia news source and the official external broadcasting institution of the United States. VOA provides programming for broadcast on radio, TV, and the Internet outside of the U.S., in English and some foreign languages. (Wikipedia)

voiceofsandiego.org.name: Voice of San Diego
voiceofsandiego.org.notes: Voice of San Diego is a nonprofit news organization focused on issues affecting the San Diego region.  Provides neutral reporting that is factual and sourced.

votesmart.org.name: Vote Smart
votesmart.org.notes: Vote Smart, formerly called Project Vote Smart (PVS), is a non-profit, non-partisan research organization that collects and distributes information on candidates for public office in the United States. It covers candidates and elected officials in six basic areas: background information, issue positions (via the Political Courage Test), voting records, campaign finances, interest group ratings, and speeches and public statements.  Vote Smart does not accept contributions from corporations, labor unions, political parties, or other organizations that lobby, support or oppose candidates or issues.  (Wikipedia) This is a solid resource.

warontherocks.com.name: War on the Rocks
warontherocks.com.notes: War on the Rocks is a website that reports on national security, defense and military.  The articles are presented with minimal biased words, are credibly sourced and presented with minimal political bias. War on the Rocks also has commentary that varies in bias from left-center to right-center, but again, is almost always sourced back to credible sources.

wearethemighty.com.name: We Are The Mighty
wearethemighty.com.notes: We Are The Mighty provides news to military personnel. The content is news that is related to or impacts those who have served or are serving in the military.  The news is delivered with minimal bias.

wikipedia.org.name: Wikipedia
wikipedia.org.notes: Wikipedia is a free-content encyclopedia project based on an openly editable model.  Wikipedia’s articles provide links to guide the user to related pages with additional information.  Most content on Wikipedia is well sourced with minimal bias, however there are some entries that have not been vetted properly and need to be checked. Always look at the sources at the bottom of the page.

wilsoncenter.org.name: Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars
wilsoncenter.org.notes: The Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars (or Wilson Center), located in Washington, D.C., is a United States Presidential Memorial that was established as part of the Smithsonian Institution by an act of Congress in 1968. It is also a highly recognized think tank, ranked among the top ten in the world.

wn.com.name: World News
wn.com.notes: World News pulls news from a variety of sources, some of which might be biased.  Good resource to find news and explore further.

worldpoliticsreview.com.name: World Politics Review
worldpoliticsreview.com.notes: World Politics Review provides uncompromising analysis of critical global trends to give policymakers, analysts, academics and readers with a deep interest in international affairs the context they need to have the confidence they want. Provides low biased reporting that is factually sourced.

worldpress.org.name: World Press Review
worldpress.org.notes: World Press Review (Worldpress.org) is an independent, nonpartisan New York based magazine founded in 1974. Worldpress.org publishes originally written articles and analysis on various world issues from environment and human rights to regional politics and armed conflicts. According to its editorial guideline, Worldpress.org mostly focuses on the issues which are barely reflected in the mainstream press, translating, reprinting, analyzing, and contextualizing what it evaluates as “the best of the international press” from more than 20 languages. For its originally written material, World Press relies on its web of freelancers from approximately 40 countries. This source also has a fantastic world newspapers directory that shows editorial bias. Overall, this is a low biased, excellent source. (D. Van Zandt)

wral.com.name: WRAL
wral.com.notes: WRAL-TV, channel 5, is a television station located in Raleigh, North Carolina, United States. It has been the flagship station of the Capitol Broadcasting Company since its inception, and serves as the NBC affiliate for the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill-Fayetteville area, known collectively as the Triangle region. WRAL reports news factually and with minimal bias. Leans just slightly left from an editorial perspective.

9news.com.au.name: 9 News (Australia)
9news.com.au.notes: Nine News is the national news service of the Nine Network in Australia. 9 News leans slightly right in reporting bias and tends to favor conservative candidates. News is well sourced and factual.

americanactionforum.org.name: American Action Forum
americanactionforum.org.notes: The American Action Forum is a nonprofit issue advocacy group based in Washington, D.C. which promotes center right public policy. They promote innovative, free-market solutions to create a smaller, smarter government.  AAF sources their information to credible sources.

acsh.org.name: American Council on Science and Health
acsh.org.notes: This source is known to be funded by corporations and tends to lean toward anti-environment issues.  Though not scientifically wrong they exhibit a bias in favor of businesses.  From Wiki: The American Council on Science and Health (ACSH) is a controversial nonprofit (501(c)(3)) advocacy organization, founded in 1978 by Elizabeth Whelan, PhD. It describes itself as a “consumer education consortium” focusing on food, nutrition, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, lifestyle, the environment and health, but others have accused it of being biased in favor of industry.

afpc.org.name: American Foreign Policy Council
afpc.org.notes: Non-Profit dedicated to providing information about foreign policy.  Has a moderate right wing bias with Republican politicians on the board.

antiwar.com.name: Anti-War
antiwar.com.notes: Antiwar.com is a libertarian website which describes itself as devoted to “non-interventionism” and as opposing imperialism and war. It is a project of the Randolph Bourne Institute. Although the website has a right leaning bias in reporting it does feature many writers from across the political spectrum, including conservatives such as Pat Buchanan, libertarians such as Ron Paul, and leftists such as Noam Chomsky and Juan Cole.

arabnews.com.name: Arab News
arabnews.com.notes: Arab News is an English-language daily newspaper published in Saudi Arabia. It is published simultaneously from Jeddah, Riyadh, and Dammam. The target audiences of the paper which is published in broadsheet are businessmen, executives and diplomats.

azcentral.com.name: Arizona Republic
azcentral.com.notes: The Arizona Republic is an American daily newspaper published in Phoenix. Circulated throughout Arizona, it is the state’s largest newspaper. Since 2000, it has been owned by the Gannett newspaper chain. Reports news factually and has a right-center editorial bias.

arkansasonline.com.name: Arkansas Democrat-Gazette
arkansasonline.com.notes: The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette is the newspaper of record in the U.S. state of Arkansas, printed in Little Rock with a northwest edition published in Lowell. It is distributed for sale in all 75 of Arkansas’ counties.

bostonherald.com.name: Boston Herald
bostonherald.com.notes: The Boston Herald is an American daily newspaper whose primary market is Boston, Massachusetts and its surrounding area. It was founded in 1846 and is one of the oldest daily newspapers in the United States. It has been awarded eight Pulitzer Prizes in its history.  The Boston Herald has a moderately conservative editorial department and typically endorses Republican candidates.

breakingdefense.com.name: Breaking Defense
breakingdefense.com.notes: Breaking Defense is an online defense magazine. They have a right-center political affiliation as they tend to support more authoritarian military use. However, they are well sourced and use minimal loaded words.

calgarysun.com.name: Calgary Sun
calgarysun.com.notes: The Calgary Sun is a daily tabloid newspaper published in Calgary, Alberta, Canada.  Has a moderate conservative editorial bias.

capoliticalreview.com.name: California Political Review
capoliticalreview.com.notes: The California Political Review is a website dedicated to California politics and especially spending and taxes. This source has a conservative political bias and is typically well sourced in presenting numbers and statistics.

cato.org.name: Cato Institute
cato.org.notes: The Cato Institute is an American libertarian think tank with a moderate right wing bias that is headquartered in Washington, D.C. It was founded as the Charles Koch Foundation in 1974 by Ed Crane, Murray Rothbard, and Charles Koch.  In July 1976, the name was changed to the Cato Institute.   The mission of the Cato Institute is to originate, disseminate, and increase understanding of public policies based on the principles of individual liberty, limited government, free markets, and peace.

c4ss.org.name: Center for a Stateless Society
c4ss.org.notes: The Center for a Stateless Society (C4SS) is an anarchist think-tank and media center. Its mission is to explain and defend the idea of vibrant social cooperation without aggression, oppression, or centralized authority.

christianitytoday.com.name: Christianity Today
christianitytoday.com.notes: Christianity Today magazine is an evangelical Christian periodical that was founded in 1956 and is based in Carol Stream, Illinois. The Washington Post calls Christianity Today, “evangelicalism’s flagship magazine.” Christianity Today reports on news and politics with minimal emotional words and sources to credible information. Politically they have a moderate conservative bias as would be expected of Evangelical Christianity.

cincinnati.com.name: Cincinnati Enquirer
cincinnati.com.notes: Cincinnati daily newspaper. Is factual in reporting, has a right-center editorial bias.

gazette.com.name: Colorado Springs Gazette
gazette.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Colorado Springs, Colorado. Has a right-center editorial bias.

dispatch.com.name: Columbus Dispatch
dispatch.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Columbus, Ohio. Factual reporting with a right of center editorial bias.

commdiginews.com.name: Communities Digital News
commdiginews.com.notes: Was at one time a part of the Washington Times, but is now its own entity.  Has a similar right of center bias as the Washington Times.

cei.org.name: Competitive Enterprise Institute
cei.org.notes: The Competitive Enterprise Institute (CEI) is a non-profit, libertarian think tank in the United States. Founded by Fred L. Smith, Jr., on March 9, 1984, in Washington, D.C., it seeks to advance economic liberty by fighting excessive government regulation because it believes that a free marketplace that allows entrepreneurship and innovation to thrive is better policy.  This source is sometimes questionable when dealing with consensus science, but typically sources to credible information. Has a pro-libertarian bias.

cfr.org.name: Council on Foreign Relations
cfr.org.notes: The Council on Foreign Relations (CFR), founded in 1921, is a United States 4900-member organization, nonprofit, publisher, and think tank specializing in U.S. foreign policy and international affairs. Has a right-center bias in reporting and is factually sourced.

dailypress.com.name: Daily Press
dailypress.com.notes: The Daily Press Inc. is a daily morning newspaper published in Newport News, Virginia, which covers the lower and middle Peninsula of Tidewater Virginia. It was established in 1896. The Daily Press reports news factually and is well sourced. Has a right of center editorial bias through their endorsement of small government fiscal conservatism.

telegraph.co.uk.name: Daily Telegraph
telegraph.co.uk.notes: The Daily Telegraph is a broadsheet newspaper published in London by Telegraph Media Group and distributed across the United Kingdom and internationally. The Daily Telegraph has a politically conservative bias in topic selection and wording, but is usually well sourced and factual in reporting.

dallasnews.com.name: Dallas Morning News
dallasnews.com.notes: The Dallas Morning News is a daily newspaper serving the Dallas–Fort Worth area of Texas.  Has a right of center editorial bias throughout its long history.

desmoinesregister.com.name: The Des Moines Register
desmoinesregister.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Iowa. The Des Moines Register is factual in reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

deseretnews.com.name: Deseret News
deseretnews.com.notes: The Deseret News is a newspaper published in Salt Lake City, Utah, United States. It is Utah’s oldest continuously published daily newspaper and has the largest Sunday circulation in the state and the second largest daily circulation behind The Salt Lake Tribune. The editorial tone of the Deseret News is usually described as moderate to conservative, and is often assumed to reflect the values of its owner, the Church of Latter Day Saints. For example, the newspaper does not accept advertising that violates church standards. DN uses minimal loaded words and always sources to credible information. Bias is based on somewhat conservative political positions.

desertsun.com.name: Desert Sun
desertsun.com.notes: The Desert Sun is a local daily newspaper serving Palm Springs and the surrounding Coachella Valley in Southern California. Factual reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

detroitnews.com.name: Detroit News
detroitnews.com.notes: The Detroit News is a daily newspaper from Detroit, Michigan.  Has a right-center editorial bias.

edmontonsun.com.name: Edmonton Sun
edmontonsun.com.notes: The Edmonton Sun is a daily tabloid newspaper and news website published in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. Factual Reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

financialpost.com.name: Financial Post
financialpost.com.notes: The Financial Post is a Canadian English-language financial newspaper.  This paper has a right of center editorial bias, but is responsible in reporting and links to credible information.

jacksonville.com.name: Florida Times-Union
jacksonville.com.notes: The Florida Times-Union is a major daily newspaper in Jacksonville, Florida, USA. Widely known as the oldest newspaper in the state, it began publication as the Florida Union in 1864. Has a right-center editorial bias and is factual in reporting.

forbes.com.name: Forbes
forbes.com.notes: Forbes is an American business magazine. Published bi-weekly, it features original articles on finance, industry, investing, and marketing topics. Forbes also reports on related subjects such as technology, communications, science, and law.

foreignpolicyi.org.name: Foreign Policy Initiative
foreignpolicyi.org.notes: The Foreign Policy Initiative (FPI) is an American think tank. According to its website, the FPI is committed to robust support for democratic allies, human rights, a strong American military equipped to meet the challenges of the 21st century, and strengthening America’s global economic competitiveness. FPI is aligned right of center politically through its stance on military and is factually sourced.

fpri.org.name: Foreign Policy Research Institute
fpri.org.notes: The Foreign Policy Research Institute (FPRI) is an American think tank based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.  The Institute conducts research on geopolitics, international relations, and international security in the various regions of the world as well as on ethnic conflict, U.S. national security, terrorism, and on think tanks themselves. Has a right of center political bias in reporting, but is highly factual and sourced.

fortune.com.name: Fortune Magazine
fortune.com.notes: Fortune is a multinational business magazine, published and owned by Time Inc. and headquartered in New York City. The publication was founded by Henry Luce in 1929. The magazine competes with Forbes and Bloomberg Businessweek in the national business magazine category.

fee.org.name: Foundation for Economic Education
fee.org.notes: Non-profit organization in teaching the principles of a free society with a right of center bias since its founding in 1946.

franklincenterhq.org.name: Franklin Center for Government and Public Integrity
franklincenterhq.org.notes: The Franklin Center for Government and Public Integrity is an online nonprofit news organization in the United States that publishes news and commentary from a free market, limited government perspective on state and local politics. The Franklin Center publishes Watchdog.org, a network of state-based websites. According to Sourcewatch the Franklin Center has a right wing position on climate change and has been criticized for rejecting the consensus of science. This source is also funded by corporations from the fossil fuel industries.

freedomhouse.org.name: Freedom House
freedomhouse.org.notes: Freedom House is a U.S.-based nonpartisan 501(c)(3) U.S. Government funded non-governmental organisation (NGO) that conducts research and advocacy on democracy, political freedom, and human rights. Freedom House was founded in October 1941. Freedom House has been criticized for excessively criticizing states opposed to US interests while being unduly sympathetic to regimes supportive of US interests. Though factual and well sourced they do have a right-center bias in both reporting and political affiliation.

mlive.com/grand-rapids.name: Grand Rapids Press
mlive.com/grand-rapids.notes: The Grand Rapids Press is a daily newspaper published in Grand Rapids, Michigan.  Typically endorses Republican candidates and a right-center editorial bias.

group30.org.name: Group of Thirty
group30.org.notes: The Group of Thirty, often abbreviated to G30, is an international body of leading financiers and academics which aims to deepen understanding of economic and financial issues and to examine consequences of decisions made in the public and private sectors related to these issues. Topical areas within the interest of the group include: the foreign exchange market, international capital markets, international financial institutions, central banks and their supervision of financial services and markets, and macroeconomic issues such as product and labor markets. Has a right leaning economic bias toward free market capitalism.

gulfnews.com.name: Gulf News
gulfnews.com.notes: Gulf News is a daily English language newspaper published from Dubai. The Gulf News has a pro-Dubai bias and also has anti-Israel views. Reports USA news with a right of center reporting bias.

heraldsun.com.au.name: Herald-Sun
heraldsun.com.au.notes: The Herald Sun is a morning tabloid newspaper based in Melbourne, Australia. It is published by The Herald and Weekly Times, a subsidiary of News Corp Australia, itself a subsidiary of News Corp. Reports factually and has a right-center editorial bias.

hpenews.com.name: High Point Enterprise
hpenews.com.notes: Daily newspaper from High Point North Carolina. Is factual in reporting, but has a right-Center editorial bias.

thehindubusinessline.com.name: The Hindu Business Line
thehindubusinessline.com.notes: Business Line or The Hindu Business Line is an Indian business newspaper published by Kasturi & Sons, the publishers of the newspaper The Hindu located in Chennai, India. Is primarily a financial media outlet with a slight right economic bias.

honestreporting.com.name: Honest Reporting
honestreporting.com.notes: HonestReporting (or Honest Reporting) is a pro-Israel, non-governmental organization that monitors the media for what it perceives as bias against Israel. The organization is a United States 501(c)3 registered charity headquartered in Skokie, Illinois, with its editorial staff based in Jerusalem, Israel. It has affiliates in the United States, UK, Canada, Italy, and Brazil. HonestReporting is generally factual, but does have a strong pro-Israel bias.

hoover.org.name: Hoover Institution
hoover.org.notes: The Hoover Institution is an American public policy think tank and research institution located at Stanford University in California. The Hoover Institution has a right-center bias in reporting and political affiliation. They also have published some articles that do not support the consensus of science.

humanprogress.org.name: Human Progress
humanprogress.org.notes: Human Progress attempts to show how capitalism and free markets have led to progress for humanity.  HumanProgress.org is a project of the Cato Institute and has corporate funding. Has right-center bias in reporting and sometimes promotes pseudoscience.

theihs.org.name: Institute for Humane Studies
theihs.org.notes: The Institute for Humane Studies (IHS) is a libertarian non-profit organization that engages with students and professors throughout the United States to encourage the study and advancement of freedom. IHS has received funding from a number of foundations, including the Sarah Scaife Foundation, the John Templeton Foundation, the F.M. Kirby Foundation, the Marcus Foundation, the John William Pope Foundation, the Ed Uihlein Family Foundation, the Ralph Smeed Private Memorial Foundation, the Koch Family Foundations, the Searle Freedom Trust, the E.L. Craig Foundation, and the Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation. This source reports factually and is sourced properly. Has a Right-Center political affiliation.

investors.com.name: Investors Business Daily
investors.com.notes: Investor’s Business Daily (IBD) is an American media company covering international business, finance, economics and the stock market.   IBD allows lobbyists and PR reps for right wing think tanks like the Heartland Institute and the Competitive Enterprise Institute to write pseudo-scientific propaganda.

independent.ie.name: Irish Independent
independent.ie.notes: The Irish Independent is the flagship publication of Independent News & Media (INM) and Ireland’s largest-selling daily newspaper. Is factual in reporting news, but has a populist conservative editorial bias.

israelhayom.com/site/today.php.name: Israel Hayom
israelhayom.com/site/today.php.notes: Israel Hayom (Israel Today) is an Israeli national Hebrew language free daily newspaper, first published in 2007. It has the largest daily circulation in the country.  Has a very strong Netanyahu bias and right-center political bias in reporting.

itv.com/news.name: ITV News
itv.com/news.notes: ITV News is the branding of news programmes on the British television network ITV. ITV News has the second-largest television news audience in the United Kingdom, second only to BBC News. ITV has a slight right-center bias in reporting.

japantoday.com.name: Japan Today
japantoday.com.notes: Japan Today is an online newspaper based in Tokyo, Japan. Launched in September 2000, Japan Today publishes wire articles, press releases, and photographs, as well as opinion and contract pieces, such as company profiles, in English. Japan Today uses appropriate sources and is generally factual in reporting. There is a right-center editorial bias and some articles tend to favor Republican political positions in the USA.

justfactsdaily.com.name: Just Facts Daily
justfactsdaily.com.notes: Just Facts Daily (JFD) is a news, opinion and fact checking website with a right-center bias in reporting. JFD’s tagline is “Be Informed, Not Just Opinionated.” This website is certainly informative, but it also appears to be quite opinionated. First, lets look at factual reporting. We could not find any evidence of JFD making certified false claims. Each article is also impeccably sourced to credible information to convey their narrative. Therefore, we rate them high for factual reporting. The right-center bias designation comes from multiple factors. First, there is excessive use of loaded emotional words in the headlines. The following loaded words (words that attempt to influence through positive or negative emotion) were found in the first 15 headlines: Incompetent, Dishonest, Catastrophically, Deceitful, Brazen Lie, Smearing, Deadly Falsehoods. Most of these words appeared in headlines when the topic was about liberal politicians or liberal policy. Further, the headlines that described conservative policy did not contain these negative connotations. They were mostly neutral in wording.

reviewjournal.com.name: Las Vegas Review Journal
reviewjournal.com.notes: The Las Vegas Review-Journal is a major daily newspaper published in Las Vegas, Nevada since 1909. It is the largest circulating daily newspaper in Nevada, and one of two daily newspapers in the Las Vegas area. The paper usually takes what is perceived to be a libertarian editorial stance.

learnliberty.org.name: Learn Liberty
learnliberty.org.notes: In 2010, the Institute for Humane Studies launched LearnLiberty.org, a website producing educational videos on libertarian ideas. The site’s stated goals are “to provide a starting point for conversations on important questions: What is the nature of man and society? What are the best ways to organize human society? What is the proper role for government?” Reports with a right-center bias in story selection and political affiliation. Sources to credible information and has a clean fact check record.

lexingtoninstitute.org.name: Lexington Institute
lexingtoninstitute.org.notes: The goal of the Lexington Institute to inform, educate, and shape the public debate of national priorities in those areas that are of surpassing importance to the future success of democracy, such as national security, education reform, tax reform, immigration and federal policy concerning science and technology

libertyviral.com.name: Liberty Viral
libertyviral.com.notes: Liberty Viral claims to be a website for people who love individual liberty and free markets. Liberty Viral reports news related to libertarianism and free market economics. There is little use of loaded words and articles are well sourced to factual information. We give it a right-center reporting bias based on their advocacy for small government and free market capitalism.

lfpress.com.name: London Free Press
lfpress.com.notes: The London Free Press is a daily newspaper based in London, Ontario, Canada. It has the largest circulation of any newspaper in Southwestern Ontario. Reports factually and with proper sources. Has a right of center editorial bias.

dailynews.com.name: Los Angeles Daily News
dailynews.com.notes: The Los Angeles Daily News is the second-largest-circulating paid daily newspaper of Los Angeles, California. The LA Daily News reports and publishes news factually. They have endorsed both Democrat and Republican candidates, but tend to lean right editorially.

mackinac.org.name: Mackinac Center for Public Policy
mackinac.org.notes: The Mackinac Center for Public Policy is an American non-profit free market think tank headquartered in Midland, Michigan. It is the largest state-based free market think tank in the United States. Generally reports factually with a right center economic bias.

macleans.ca.name: Maclean’s Magazine
macleans.ca.notes: Maclean’s is a Canadian weekly news magazine that was founded in 1905, reporting on Canadian issues such as politics, pop culture, and current events. Has right of center bias in reporting and wording, but well sourced and factual.

manhattan-institute.org.name: Manhattan Institute for Policy Research
manhattan-institute.org.notes: The Manhattan Institute for Policy Research is an American think tank established in New York City in 1978 by Antony Fisher and William J. Casey.  The primary focus is on economics and law enforcement. Has a right-center bias in reporting and affiliation.

militarytimes.com.name: Military Times
militarytimes.com.notes: The Military Times publishes news related to the military and defense.  This source’s target audience is current and former military personnel. Has a right-center political bias in reporting.

mises.org.name: Mises Daily
mises.org.notes: The Ludwig von Mises Institute (LvMI), often referred to as the Mises Institute, is a tax-exempt organization located in Auburn, Alabama, United States. It is named after Austrian School economist Ludwig von Mises (1881–1973). Its website states that it exists to promote “teaching and research in the Austrian school of economics, and individual freedom, honest history, and international peace, in the tradition of Ludwig von Mises and Murray N. Rothbard.” The Mises Daily produces news that has a right wing economic bias and sometimes sources to other highly biased right wing sources. Does not always support the consensus of science as exampled by anti-science advocate Lew Rockwell serving as Chairman.

nakedcapitalism.com.name: Naked Capitalism
nakedcapitalism.com.notes: Naked Capitalism is an American financial news and analysis blog that “chronicles the large scale, concerted campaign to reduce the bargaining power and pay of ordinary workers relative to investors and elite technocrats.” Naked Capitalism is well sourced and does not use many loaded words. Holds a right of center political fiscal view.

nationalinterest.org.name: National Interest
nationalinterest.org.notes: The National Interest (TNI) is an American bi-monthly international affairs magazine published by the Center for the National Interest. It is associated with the realist school of foreign policy thought.  This is a strong source for foreign affairs with mostly balanced reporting.

nationalpost.com/index.html.name: National Post
nationalpost.com/index.html.notes: The National Post is a Canadian English-language newspaper.  This paper has a conservative bias, but is responsible in reporting, therefore we give it a Right-Center bias due to quality reporting.

nypost.com.name: New York Post
nypost.com.notes: A daily tabloid type newspaper from New York City.  This source can swing very far to the right, but does occasionally provide a balanced account.  Not a very credible source overall.

newsheist.com.name: News Heist
newsheist.com.notes: News Heist is a news curation website that does not produce any original content.  All news links go to external sources.  In reviewing several news links, they went to a variety of left and right sources, some also went to Zero Hedge, which we classify as a conspiracy website. The selected news stories tend to lean to the right.  We give this source a mixed factual rating because of links to a known conspiracy site.  Further, this source does not have an about page, disclaimer or any other information about their purpose or ownership.

newsrescue.com.name: News Rescue
newsrescue.com.notes: News Rescue is a Nigerian news and opinion website with a right-center bias. Unfortunately, this source does not have an “about” page, so it is difficult to understand their mission. In reviewing articles this source uses minimal loaded words, but does tend to favor stories that are right of center. Stories are sourced appropriately.

oilprice.com.name: Oil Price
oilprice.com.notes: Oilprice.com provides updated Oil and energy prices. They also have information and articles written by journalists and analysts in the Energy, Political and Economic space.  Has a right of center view.

omaha.com.name: Omaha World-Herald
omaha.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Omaha, Nebraska. Is factual reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

ocregister.com.name: Orange County Register
ocregister.com.notes: Right of center daily newspaper from Orange County California.

oregonlive.com.name: Oregonian
oregonlive.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Portland, Oregon. Is factual in reporting with right-center editorial bias.

orlandosentinel.com.name: Orlando Sentinel
orlandosentinel.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Orlando, Florida with a right-center editorial bias.

pacificresearch.org/home.name: Pacific Research Institute
pacificresearch.org/home.notes: The Pacific Research Institute for Public Policy (PRI) is a California-based free-market think tank which promotes “the principles of individual freedom and personal responsibility” through policies that emphasize a free economy, private initiative, and limited government. PRI was founded in 1979 by British philanthropist Antony Fisher

peninsuladailynews.com.name: Peninsula Daily News
peninsuladailynews.com.notes: The Peninsula Daily News is a daily newspaper printed Sundays through Fridays, covering the northern Olympic Peninsula in the state of Washington, United States.  They have a slight right of center bias with reporting and editorials.

triblive.com.name: Pittsburgh Tribune Review
triblive.com.notes: The Pittsburgh Tribune Reviews is a daily newspaper from Pittsburgh Pennsylvania. They are factual in reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

policyed.org.name: PolicyEd
policyed.org.notes: Policyed.org is a website that is affiliated with the Hoover Institution that covers US policy and promotes free market capitalism. They generally report with minimal loaded words and good sourcing. They have a right wing political affiliation.

postbulletin.com.name: Post-Bulletin
postbulletin.com.notes: The Post-Bulletin is a daily newspaper based in Rochester, Minnesota. The Post-Bulletin reports news factually and sources to credible information. There is a slight right bias in reporting and editorial bias, hence we rate Post-Bulletin Right-Center.

publicinterestlegal.org.name: Public Interest Legal Foundation
publicinterestlegal.org.notes: Founded in 2012, PILF is a 501(c)(3) public interest law firm dedicated entirely to election integrity. The Foundation exists to assist states and others to aid the cause of election integrity and fight against lawlessness in American elections. Drawing on numerous experts in the field, the Foundation seeks to protect the right to vote and preserve the Constitutional framework of American elections.

punchingbagpost.com.name: PunchingBag Post
punchingbagpost.com.notes: PunchingBag Post has the tagline “A Conservative Perspective.”  Although they clearly reveal their bias, they really do not overtly show it in reporting.  Most headlines match the content of news articles, it has decent sourcing, and only moderately favors right wing stories.

quillette.com.name: Quillette
quillette.com.notes: Quillette is a well written online magazine with a libertarian leaning bias. All articles are well sourced and mostly free of loaded language. We rate this source right-center based on right leaning political bias. Otherwise this is a factual and well written source.

realcleardefense.com.name: Real Clear Defense
realcleardefense.com.notes: A division of Real Clear Politics that focuses on military issues.

realclearinvestigations.com.name: Real Clear Investigations
realclearinvestigations.com.notes: A division of Real Clear Politics that focuses on investigations.

realclearpolitics.com.name: Real Clear Politics
realclearpolitics.com.notes: Primary reports on political polls, but does have news articles with a right-center bias.

reason.com.name: Reason
reason.com.notes: Reason is an American libertarian monthly magazine published by the Reason Foundation. The magazine has a circulation of around 50,000 and was named one of the 50 best magazines in 2003 and 2004 by the Chicago Tribune. Is generally factual and sourced properly with a right-center reporting bias.

valleynewslive.com.name: Red River Valley News
valleynewslive.com.notes: Red River Valley News broadcasts on KVLY 17 hours of news per week, with 4 1/2 hours on weekdays and 1 1/2 on the weekends between the main NBC channel and the CBS-affiliated KXJB-LD.  They claim to lead the news market in Fargo, North Dakota. Has a right-center editorial bias.

cato.org/regulation.name: Regulation Magazine
cato.org/regulation.notes: Regulation is a quarterly periodical about policy published by the Cato Institute. It was started as a bimonthly magazine in 1977 by the American Enterprise Institute and acquired by Cato in 1989. Past editors have included former Supreme Court justice Antonin Scalia, Murray Weidenbaum, Christopher DeMuth,Walter Olson, and Peter Huber. Peter Van Doren has edited the magazine since 1999. Regulation has a right-center bias with fiscal politics and anti-regulation policy. They sometimes source to highly biased sources.

richmond.com.name: Richmond Times-Dispatch
richmond.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Richmond, Virginia with a right-center editorial bias.

rt.com/news.name: RT News
rt.com/news.notes: RT, originally Russia Today, is a television network funded by the Russian government. It operates cable and satellite television channels directed to audiences outside of Russia as well as providing Internet content in various languages, including Russian. It has right of center coverage of the USA.  Highly biased toward Russia and occasionally runs Pro-state conspiracy stories.

russia-insider.com/en.name: Russia Insider
russia-insider.com/en.notes: Russia Insider is a news website launched in September 2014, based in Moscow, Russia. Russia Insider reports on political and social affairs and aims to provide an alternative view to the mainstream news about Russia and country-related issues. Its mission is media criticism and reform, underlining the issues of Western media which are seen by the founders as extremely biased, especially on Russia. The website was criticized for its pro-Russian stance, considered to be alongside several highly visible partisan outlets such as RT, Ruptly and Sputnik. Has a right-center bias in reporting and sometimes sources to questionable media outlets such as Infowars.

tass.com.name: Russian News Agency-TASS
tass.com.notes: Russian News Agency TASS  is a major news agency in Russia, founded in 1902. Tass is the largest Russian news agency, and the fourth largest in the world after Reuters, the Associated Press (AP) and Agence France-Presse (AFP). Tass is owned by the Government of Russia. TASS has a very strong pro-Russian bias, especially as it relates to news regarding the Ukraine. When reporting non-Russian news they report with minimal loaded words and factually source their information. Editorially, they have a right of center bias.

srnnews.com.name: Salem Radio Network News (SRN News)
srnnews.com.notes: Salem Radio Network News is owned by the Salem Radio Network. The SRN News website features news and opinion reports that are very well sourced, neutral in language and factual. The editorial position of SRN News is conservative, with conservative radio hosts Michael Medved, Hugh Hewitt and Dennis Prager providing content.

sandiegouniontribune.com.name: San Diego Union Tribune
sandiegouniontribune.com.notes: The San Diego Union-Tribune is an American metropolitan daily newspaper, published in San Diego, California. They are factual in reporting with a right-center editorial bias.

sofrep.com.name: SOFREP
sofrep.com.notes: SOFREP is a news and opinion website founded and run by Brandon Webb, a former Navy Seal and Sniper Instructor. The website provides news and analysis from Special Operations Combat Veterans. Most information on the website is well sourced and factual. There is little use of loaded words and articles match headlines. There is a right-center bias in reporting which is expected from a source that is very pro-military.

sun-sentinel.com.name: South Florida Sun-Sentinel
sun-sentinel.com.notes: The Sun-Sentinel is the main daily newspaper of Broward County, Florida. Owned by Tronc, it circulates all throughout the three counties that comprise South Florida. It is the largest-circulation newspaper in the area (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias.

spokesman.com.name: The Spokesman-Review
spokesman.com.notes: The Spokesman-Review is a daily broadsheet newspaper based in Spokane in U.S. state of Washington, where it is the city’s only daily publication.

sputniknews.com.name: Sputnik News
sputniknews.com.notes: Russian news media company out of Moscow.  Is pro-Russian government and favors Republicans in the USA.  Has been known to publish conspiracies.  Take them with a grain of salt.

star-telegram.com.name: Star Telegram
star-telegram.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Fort Worth, Texas with a right-center editorial bias.

statesmanjournal.com.name: Statesman Journal
statesmanjournal.com.notes: A right of center subsidiary of USA Today.

strategic-culture.org.name: Strategic Culture Foundation
strategic-culture.org.notes: According to their website the Strategic Culture Foundation provides a platform for exclusive analysis, research and policy comment on Eurasian and global affairs. This source has a very strong pro-Russian bias, however they do source their information well.

studentnewsdaily.com.name: Student Daily News
studentnewsdaily.com.notes: Student News Daily (SND) is a site that provides, as the name suggests, current news and information to students. It provides almost no original content, but instead links to stories from a wide range of external news sources as diverse as Reuters and The Daily Caller. Additionally, SND provides questions for the student after the articles intended to promote critical thinking on the issues. Due to the diverse variety of the news sources, the factual content and political bias of the articles ranges from very high to very low. Although there is a slight preference for Right Center news sources, where SND’s bias is most evident is in their Recommended Sites list. The list of links are primarily Right Center, Right Bias, or government fact sites. This, coupled with the slight Right Center slant in the article selection earns SND a Right Center rating. (D. Kelley)

tallahassee.com.name: Tallahassee Democrat
tallahassee.com.notes: The Tallahassee Democrat is a daily broadsheet newspaper. It covers the area centered on Tallahassee in Leon County, Florida, as well as adjacent Gadsden County, Jefferson County, and Wakulla County. The newspaper is owned by Gannett Co., Inc. Presents news factually, with strong sources and with minimal bias. Has a conservative editorial board.

tbo.com.name: Tampa Tribune
tbo.com.notes: The Tampa Tribune was an online newspaper published in Tampa, Florida.  Has a consistent right wing editorial stance.  Endorses Republican candidates.

taxfoundation.org.name: Tax Foundation
taxfoundation.org.notes: The Tax Foundation is an independent Washington, D.C.-based think tank, founded in 1937, that collects data and publishes research studies on U.S. tax policies at both the federal and state levels.  It describes itself as an “independent tax policy research organization”. They are cited in the media as a nonpartisan or bipartisan organization, and are also described as business-friendly or conservative. Well sourced information.

tharawat-magazine.com.name: Tharawat Magazine
tharawat-magazine.com.notes: Tharawat Magazine is a business and financial magazine.  Has a slight rightward bias, but it is minimal.

algemeiner.com.name: The Algemeiner Journal
algemeiner.com.notes: The Algemeiner Journal is a New York-based newspaper, covering American and international Jewish and Israel-related news. Is typically well sourced with a right-center editorial bias.

theamericanconservative.com.name: The American Conservative
theamericanconservative.com.notes: The American Conservative (TAC) is a bi-monthly journal of opinion published by the American Ideas Institute. It has argued against American interventionism, against a debt-based fiscal policy, and against the intrusions on Americans’ private lives by the institutions and mores that exist and the wisdom that underlies them. Very well written source with a libertarian perspective.

the-american-interest.com.name: The American Interest
the-american-interest.com.notes: The American Interest (AI) is a bimonthly magazine focusing primarily on foreign policy, international affairs, global economics, and military matters.  Excellent journalism with a slight right of center bias.

theaustralian.com.au.name: The Australian
theaustralian.com.au.notes: The Australian is a broadsheet newspaper published in Australia from Monday to Saturday each week since 14 July 1964.  It is the biggest-selling national newspaper in the country. Has a right-center editorial bias.

couriermail.com.au.name: The Courier Mail
couriermail.com.au.notes: The Courier-Mail is a daily tabloid newspaper published in Brisbane, Australia and owned by News Corp Australia. The Courier Mail has a right-center in bias in reporting and uses sensational headlines that is typical of a tabloid. They support free-market economics and usually publish factual information.

thefiscaltimes.com.name: The Fiscal Times
thefiscaltimes.com.notes: The Fiscal Times has a right of center economic bias.  Well sourced and factual in reporting.

thegazette.com.name: The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)
thegazette.com.notes: The Gazette is a daily newspaper published in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. The newspaper is distributed throughout northeastern and east-central Iowa, including the Cedar Rapids and Iowa City metropolitan areas. It was formerly called The Cedar Rapids Gazette. The newspaper presents news stories with minimal bias and always sources properly. Although the newspaper endorsed Hillary Clinton in 2016, it has endorsed Republicans every election since 1964. Therefore, the editorial bias favors Republican’s and is right of center.

independent.org.name: The Independent Review
independent.org.notes: Is a non-profit, non-partisan, scholarly research and educational organization that sponsors in-depth studies of critical social and economic issues. Has a right wing political bias in reporting, but is well sourced with credible information.

jamestown.org.name: The Jamestown Foundation
jamestown.org.notes: Their mission is to inform and educate policy makers and the broader community about events and trends in those societies which are strategically or tactically important to the United States and which frequently restrict access to such information. Has a strong pro-military bias.

the-japan-news.com.name: The Japan News
the-japan-news.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Japan with a right-center editorial bias as it relates to western news.

jewishpress.com.name: The Jewish Press
jewishpress.com.notes: The Jewish Press is an American weekly newspaper based in Brooklyn, New York and geared toward the modern Orthodox Jewish community. The Jewish Press covers the Jewish news from New York City, the United States, and Israel. The newspaper has a politically conservative viewpoint and editorial policy according to their about page. Our review indicates the minimal use of loaded language and generally well sourced content. There is a definite right leaning/pro-Israel bias editorially.

thelibertarianrepublic.com.name: The Libertarian Republic
thelibertarianrepublic.com.notes: The Libertarian Republic is a free market news, culture, and opinion magazine featuring the writing of prominent libertarians, conservatives, independents and sometimes democrats. The goal of TLR is to inform and educate citizens on important news stories from a perspective of economic freedom and personal liberty.

thenational.ae.name: The National (UAE)
thenational.ae.notes: The National is a government-owned English-language daily newspaper published in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.  Very pro-government, but is relatively unbiased in reporting news from around the world.

oklahoman.com/live.name: The Oklahoman
oklahoman.com/live.notes: Daily Newspaper from Oklahoma with a right-center editorial bias.

pe.com.name: The Press-Enterprise
pe.com.notes: The Press-Enterprise is a paid daily newspaper published by Digital First Media that serves the Inland Empire in Southern California. Headquartered in downtown Riverside, California, it is the primary newspaper for Riverside County, with heavy penetration into neighboring San Bernardino County (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias.

thesmokinggun.com.name: The Smoking Gun
thesmokinggun.com.notes: The Smoking Gun is a website that posts legal documents, arrest records, and police mugshots on a daily basis.  They use sensational headlines to grab attention, but always link to evidence.  Although the information they cover varies there is a slight right bias in word choices.  Otherwise this is a trustworthy site for sensationalized legal and arrest stories.

spectator.co.uk.name: The Spectator (UK)
spectator.co.uk.notes: The Spectator is a weekly British conservative magazine. It was first published on 6 July 1828, making it the oldest continuously published magazine in the English language. It is currently owned by David and Frederick Barclay who also own The Daily Telegraph newspaper, via Press Holdings. Its principal subject areas are politics and culture. Its editorial outlook is generally supportive of the Conservative Party (Wikipedia).

tennessean.com.name: The Tennessean
tennessean.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Tennessee that is usually factual with a right-center editorial bias.

thewest.com.au.name: The West Australian
thewest.com.au.notes: The West Australian, widely known as The West is the only locally edited daily newspaper published in Perth, Western Australia, and is owned by Seven West Media (SWM). The West is the second-oldest continuously produced newspaper in Australia, having been published since 1833. The West tends to have conservative leanings as reflected in a right-center editorial bias. The West typically sources to credible information.

thetimes.co.uk.name: The Times of London
thetimes.co.uk.notes: The Times is a British daily (Monday to Saturday) national newspaper based in London, England. It began in 1785 under the title The Daily Universal Register, adopting its current name on 1 January 1788. The Times and its sister paper The Sunday Times (founded in 1821) are published by Times Newspapers, since 1981 a subsidiary of News UK, itself wholly owned by News Corp (Wikipedia). Has a right-center editorial bias, but is generally factual in reporting.

toledoblade.com.name: Toledo Blade
toledoblade.com.notes: The Blade, also known as the Toledo Blade, is a daily newspaper in Toledo, Ohio, in the United States, first published on December 19, 1835. Reports news factually with a slight right of center editorial bias.

wsj.com.name: Wall Street Journal
wsj.com.notes: The Wall Street Journal is a high circulation daily financial newspaper from New York City.  The WSJ is Right-Center for a very specific reason.  Their news reporting is excellent and usually very centrist with little bias, however their editorial page is moderately to significantly right.  Therefore, we say Right-Center overall.

washingtonexaminer.com.name: Washington Examiner
washingtonexaminer.com.notes: The Washington Examiner is an American political journalism website and weekly magazine based in Washington, D.C. that covers politics and policy in the United States and internationally.  The publication is influential with conservative circles in politics and government-related fields.

washingtontimes.com.name: Washington Times
washingtontimes.com.notes: Daily newspaper from Washington DC that was one of the first broadsheets in the United States to adopt color photography. The political leanings of The Washington Times are often described as conservative. (Wikipedia) They do usually source well and can be reasonably trusted for their reporting.

watchdog.org.name: Watchdog.org
watchdog.org.notes: Watchdog.org is a network of American news websites that features reporting on state and local government from a conservative perspective. It is a project of the Franklin Center for Government and Public Integrity, an online news organization. Watchdog posts stories on Watchdog websites and syndicates them. Usually well sourced with minimal loaded words. This source is funded by the fossil fuel industry and promotes anti-science stories regarding climate change.

rep-am.com.name: Waterbury Republican-American
rep-am.com.notes: The Republican-American, is a family-owned newspaper based in Waterbury, Connecticut. Has a right-center editorial bias.

kansas.com.name: Wichita Eagle
kansas.com.notes: The Wichita Eagle is a daily newspaper published in Wichita, Kansas, United States. It is owned by The McClatchy Company and is the largest newspaper in Wichita and the surrounding area. The Wichita Eagle is factually based and well sourced. They have a very slight right center editorial bias as evidenced by political endorsements that lean right.

wikileaks.org.name: WikiLeaks
wikileaks.org.notes: WikiLeaks is an international non-profit organization that publishes secret information, news leaks, and classified media from anonymous sources.  Julian Assange, an Australian Internet activist, is generally described as its founder, editor-in-chief, and director. Although it is believed that WikiLeaks publishing of classified/secret material is authentic they have been accused of promoting conspiracy theories against Hillary Clinton and the Democratic Party of the United States (See Wikipedia).  So while the material dumps are not biased they have demonstrated a political agenda.  Therefore, rather than a Least Biased rating we are moving them to Right-Center until more information comes in.

journalnow.com.name: Winston-Salem Journal
journalnow.com.notes: The Winston-Salem Journal is an American daily newspaper primarily serving the city of Winston-Salem, North Carolina, and its county, Forsyth County, North Carolina.  The paper typically endorses Republican candidates.

whitehouse.gov/1600daily.name: 1600 Daily
whitehouse.gov/1600daily.notes: 1600 Daily is a part of the Whitehouse.gov website. 1600 Daily gives news each day about what is happening within the White House, including the President’s schedule. Everything on this page is pro-Trump and pro-Republican. Essentially, it is an official looking propaganda arm for the President. 1600 Daily also publishes news stories from outside sources. Some of these sources have “mixed” factual reporting ratings. One example is a link to a news story by the Daily Caller, which is right biased and has a mixed factual reporting rating due to false claims confirmed by fact checkers. This website is useful for checking out White House schedules.

aim.org.name: Accuracy in Media (AIM)
aim.org.notes: Accuracy In Media (AIM) is an American non-profit news media watchdog founded in 1969 by economist Reed Irvine. AIM describes itself as “a non-profit, grassroots citizens watchdog of the news media that critiques botched and bungled news stories and sets the record straight on important issues that have received slanted coverage.” It has been described as having a politically conservative stance (Wikipedia). This description via Wikipedia misses the mark.  This is a strongly right wing source that often resorts to conspiracy and bigotry. They also promote pseudoscience such as intelligent design and anti-science positions on climate change.

acting-man.com.name: Acting Man
acting-man.com.notes: Acting Man is a news and opinion website as well as a forum. Acting Man has a libertarian perspective and endorses Austrian Economic Theory. Most headlines have minimal loaded words, but several articles do. For example, in the article Trump Vs. The Deep State they refer to the Obama Administration as the “Obummer Administration,” which is an old childish term for those who oppose the former President.  This instantly diminishes the credibility of the source. Further, in this same article the only source listed as a reference is Zero Hedge, which we have rated as a conspiracy website. While there is plenty of credible content on this website, there is also articles like the one described above that hurt the credibility of Acting Man.

againstcronycapitalism.org.name: Against Crony Capitialism
againstcronycapitalism.org.notes: Against Crony Capitalism is a website that works to expose crony capitalism.  ACC has a right wing bias in reporting and occasionally uses loaded words. ACC always attempts to source their information and in most cases uses credible media. However, there are time when they cite questionable sources such as in this article, where they cite SHTFplan.com for information. SHTF is classified as a questionable source according to MBFC’s methodology. While the wording is biased and they sometimes do not give full context, the information is usually rooted in fact, but not enough to justify a high factual rating.

allenbwest.com.name: Allen B. West
allenbwest.com.notes: Col. Allen West is a retired Lieutenant Colonel and the former Republican Representative from Florida’s 22nd district.  His website is a news and information site that has a far right bias and occasionally publishes right wing conspiracy theories. Has false claims according to fact checkers.

aei.org.name: American Enterprise Institute
aei.org.notes: American Enterprise Institute, or AEI, is a conservative think tank based in Washington, D.C. Its research is dedicated to issues of government, politics, economics and social welfare. Corporately funded.  Has a poor track record with scientific consensus and occasionally publishes misleading stories that blur facts.

americansforprosperity.org.name: Americans for Prosperity
americansforprosperity.org.notes: Americans for Prosperity (AFP), founded in 2004, is a conservative political advocacy group in the United States. Receiving funding from the businessmen and philanthropist brothers David H. Koch and Charles Koch, it is one of the most influential American conservative organizations. AFP has a poor track record with fact checkers.

spectator.org.name: American Spectator
spectator.org.notes: The American Spectator, is a conservative U.S. monthly magazine covering news and politics, edited by R.
